messages.subject: Confirmation of kanji/translation needed.
messages.msgSnippet: Hi all, I have been working on translating a mei for a mate. I have got it down to Ô Ryûsai Tsuki Mitsuoki. Can anyone confirm this for me. It is definitely
messages.messageBody:
Hi all, I have been working on translating a mei for a mate. I have got
it down to Ô Ryûsai Tsuki Mitsuoki.

Can anyone confirm this for me. It is definitely the Ôtsuki Mitsuoki Ha.

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/upload/images/crane%20kozuka%20sign.jpg

I cannot seem to manage posting Kanji here, I have posted this thread
also on the NMB so I have the kanji listed there as I got them form
Wakayama.

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/nmb//forum/index.php?action=display&forumid=1&msgid=850

Cheers all.

Rich

messages.subject: 2 new tsuba - id help
messages.msgSnippet: Hi all, I recently received 2 tsuba from japan.  I am trying to id them.  the 1st (labeled mantis20) has basket weave design.  I have looked through every
messages.messageBody:
Hi all,

I recently received 2 tsuba from japan. I am trying
to id them. the 1st (labeled mantis20) has basket
weave design. I have looked through every reference i
have and am thinking bushu or shoami- of course. Can
anyone give me any thoughts? Any other schools to
consider? I also have another similiar one coming
soon that was papered to the sanagawa (sp?) school, an
offshoot of ito (bushu) I believe.

The 2nd tsuba (labeled mantis21)has this subtle
sunburst on both sides of the plate under the designs.
I was trying to determine if the lines are raised or
not. They may be a little, I can't really tell.
Everytime I run my fingertips over them I go back &
forth between smooth or ridges. You can make out some
of the starburst on the right hand side of the
pictured back side to get an idea (didn't come out in
the photo much). I also can't tell if the mimi is
added seperate or not. It has been worked regardless
to give a texture. Any help on id'ing this one also
would be great, along with a guess as to age. I of
course assume they are both edo.

The photos are stored in the nihontostudy photo folder
under "mantis dude". Here is the link

http://tinyurl.com/9zvf5 or long link is
http://photos.groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/lst?.dir=/Mantis+dude&.src=gr&.order=&.view=t&.done=http%3a//briefcase.yahoo.com/

Thanks.
Ken



__________________________________
Yahoo! Mail - PC Magazine Editors' Choice 2005
http://mail.yahoo.com

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Yoshihiko
messages.msgSnippet: I do not think the first two characters are Sôshô - grass writing.  I immediately read the second one as -TO, as in GOTO  (GÔTÔ????).  Rather, I think
messages.messageBody:
I do not think the first two characters are Sôshô - "grass" writing. I
immediately read the second one as -TO, as in GOTO (GÔTÔ????). Rather, I think
they are a cursive script that is a simplifcation of the Kaishô or "block" form.
Sôshô is a very much more "simplified" form and usually completely
unrecognisable without a lot of work (I think this is a "straight" comment and
hope I'm not talking with the forked tongue of an empty vessel!!

Regards,

Barry Thomas

----- Original Message -----
From: "Gordon Robson" <robsongo@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Monday, October 03, 2005 6:30 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Yoshihiko


Hi Jim,

I would suspect you could find it in a special grass writing guide.
There are guidelines for just how to simplify or make more abstract,
but I do not posses one.

Gordon

On 2005/10/03, at 14:25, Jim Gilbert wrote:

> John,
> The kanji for Saito inscribed on the guard Rich posted match the ones
> illustrated in the photos in Wakayama. The text version of those
> kanji in Wakayama match the ones in Haynes. The carved versions of
> the kanji do look quite different from the printed ones, hence your
> confusion.
>
> The modern text version of the first kanji is so different from the
> carved one that I wouldn't recognize it on my own. The second kanji
> is a shorthand version of the printed example, but would be very
> difficult to recognize without textual context. I'd be interested in
> knowing the orthographic history of the first kanji -- it doesn't look
> like a post-war simplification. Does anyone know?
>
> Jim

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Yoshihiko
messages.msgSnippet: John, The kanji for Saito inscribed on the guard Rich posted match the ones illustrated in the photos in Wakayama.  The text version of those kanji in Wakayama
messages.messageBody:
John,
The kanji for Saito inscribed on the guard Rich posted match the ones illustrated in the photos in Wakayama. The text version of those kanji in Wakayama match the ones in Haynes. The carved versions of the kanji do look quite different from the printed ones, hence your confusion.

The modern text version of the first kanji is so different from the carved one that I wouldn't recognize it on my own. The second kanji is a shorthand version of the printed example, but would be very difficult to recognize without textual context. I'd be interested in knowing the orthographic history of the first kanji -- it doesn't look like a post-war simplification. Does anyone know?

Jim



Would someone please put me straight? The three final kanji on the
illustration certainly correspond with the alternative form for
YOSHIHIKO, as given under H 11559.0 in Haynes' Index ....But the
first two kanji do not correspond to those which he gives for
SAITO. Where am I going wrong; is this an alternative form of the
family name?

Regards, John L.



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Yoshihiko
messages.msgSnippet: John, my understanding of Kanji is not deep enough to answer that one, in the Toso Kodogu Meiji Taikan, Wakayama has is it listed one way  but the oshigata is
messages.messageBody:
John, my understanding of Kanji is not deep enough to answer that one,
in the Toso Kodogu Meiji Taikan, Wakayama has is it listed one way but
the oshigata is as the image I posted. I assume the tsubako wrote them
with 2 different kanji that read the same??

Maybe Jim or Gordon can clarify for us.

Rich

messages.messageBody:
Rafael,
I haven't heard of it. Do you know what the kanji are?

Nihon Token Hozon Kai I know.
Jim



Dear Friends,


Does any one knows the this organization " Nihonto Juto Hozon Kai " ?
Is there any website about this organization ? They have good reputation in nihonto world ?

Thanks

Rafael - Brazil

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Yoshihiko
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, The kanji didn t come through for me, but the examples at the bottom of the page in Wakayama read Saito Yoshihiko (kao).  Saito (long o) is the family
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
The kanji didn't come through for me, but the examples at the bottom of the page in Wakayama read Saito Yoshihiko (kao). Saito (long o) is the family name.

Jim



Group, there is a tsubako in the Toso Kodogu Meiji Taikan in book 3,
page 111. that signed ?? ?? Yoshihiko
Yoshi ? Hi ? Ko ? with Kao. I a looking at an exact same mei for a
friend but cannot make the first two kanji as they apear in th emei in
the book. Can anyone help please.

Cheers

Rich
